entry.title: SAP BTP ABAP Environment ‚Äì Pre-Upgrade Option for Release 2602
entry.content:
Overview

Providing a significant number of new features is an important goal of release upgrades to deliver innovations to our customers and partners. There are four major release upgrades per year following a predefined schedule as described in this blog post.

An upgrade is intended as a ‚Äúno event‚Äù for customers and partners. For example, only compatible changes of released objects (APIs) will be delivered. We recommend performing a test of the custom-built productive apps in a test environment for the new release. The complexity of the technical dependencies between the custom-built apps and the underlying environment cannot be tested isolated, only including the ABAP environment on SAP-side. Therefore, we offer you to pre-upgrade selected systems 29 days in advance to test the applications prior to the planned standard-upgrade.   

 

Purpose

This option enables a customer or partner to test the applications they have already developed on top of the new release a couple of days before the standard-upgrade. With SAP BTP ABAP Environment (aka "Steampunk"), we follow the approach of keeping released objects stable and provide all enhancements in a compatible fashion. Early testing is an additional measure to ensure proper software quality and might be used to detect unforeseen regressions. However, this option is not intended to test new features or to consume new features earlier.

 

Approach

The standard-upgrade of all systems to release 2602 is planned for February 14/15.

A customer or partner can nominate one or more already existing systems for the pre-upgrade. A nominated system will be upgraded on January 16 within a planned downtime from 8:00 to 16:00 CET. Depending on the system settings, the actual technical downtime might be only ~20 min within the mentioned timeframe. Please refer to this blog post about the downtime-optimized upgrade. 

We recommend nominating a non-development system, such as a test system. The nomination of a development system is technically also possible, but fixes or other changes must not be imported into another system with a lower release. The nomination of a productive system doesn‚Äôt make sense because the purpose of the pre-upgrade is the re-test of the existing application before the productive system gets the new release.

According to the approach explained above, this offer is only relevant for customers or partners having at least two systems.

There might be situations where a correction of custom objects needs to be deployed. Such corrections are possible if the development / correction system is on the older release and is imported into the pre-upgraded system with the higher release.

Except potential fixes, the pre-upgrade is based on the same version as the standard-upgrade. It is planned to perform the pre-upgrade based on hotfix collection 2. The pre-upgrade systems will get the import of hotfix collection 3 after 2 weeks in the middle of the entire pre-upgrade test phase. It is planned to perform the standard-upgrade based on hotfix collection 4 and import this hotfix collection 4 to the pre-upgrade systems on February 14/15 as well.

 

Costs

This offering is optional and free of any additional charges.

 

Planned New Features

The planned new features will be published on the What's New for SAP BTP ABAP Environment on January 16. This list gives you an overview of potential areas for re-testing. The purpose of the pre-upgrade is not to consume these features before the standard-upgrade, because the documentation on help.sap.com will be delivered later before the standard-upgrade. It would also not be possible to transport code of such an adoption, because subsequent systems are not yet on the new release during the pre-upgrade phase.

Independent of the upgrades of the SAP BTP ABAP Environment, we recommend developing automated tests for the custom-built apps to detect regressions early on and without manual effort for re-testing. Such automated tests are perfectly suited to be run in the pre-upgrade test phase.

 

Time Schedule

The following figure summarizes the general approach:

 

Milestones for release 2602:

  • December 16: Nomination of system(s) is possible in the Landscape Portal
  • January 16: Announcement of the planned new features
  • January 12: Pre-upgrade systems are known
  • January 16: Pre-upgrade (with hotfix collection 2)
  • January 30: Import of hotfix collection 3 into pre-upgrade systems
  • February 11: Potential decision to postpone the upgrade
  • February 14/15: Standard-upgrade (with hotfix collection 4)

 

System Nomination

To nominate a system, please register the system(s) by January 12 (EOB) latest by using the Landscape Portal. You can find further information about Accessing the Landscape Portal and about Register Systems for Pre-Upgrade. Please do not create customer tickets for system nomination like in previous pre-upgrades.

With such a nomination, the customer agrees to an extraordinary planned maintenance on January 16 (see above).

 

Report an Issue

Issues should be reported as part of the regression test phase by January 30 (EOB) to allow for a sufficient time frame for issue analysis and potential corrections on SAP-side.

Please create a customer ticket by using component BC-CP-ABA.

If a detected issue is likely to endanger the productive use after the standard-upgrade, you should use ticket priority very high despite the fact that the pre-upgrade system is not a productive system.

 

Exceptional Process in Case of Unresolved Priority Very High Issues

In case of the aligned decision on Wednesday, February 11 (based on unresolved priority very high tickets) to postpone the upgrade, a dedicated mitigation process needs to be started together with the respective customer or partner, with the following boundary conditions:

  • Resolving the open priority very high issues remains the highest priority for both, SAP and the customer or partner, as it is also the prerequisite for the upgrade.
  • According to the estimated issue resolution, catching up the upgrade needs to be planned.
  • The upgrade leads to a business downtime of 6 ‚Äì 8 hours.
  • The upgrade must be scheduled within 7 calendar days the latest after fixing all remaining open priority very high issues.
  • We will not provide any fixes for the old release after the original date of the standard-upgrade to the new release.

In case business-critical issues are detected after the upgrade:

  • Issues need to be reported as priority very high issues and will be processed accordingly.
  • Going back to the release before upgrade is not an option. Therefore, resolving the issues in the new release with the appropriate priority is the required approach.

 

Summary

We recommend performing regression tests in pre-upgraded test systems to avoid day-1 impacts of productive custom apps after the standard-upgrade.

entry.title: Group-Assignment via Entra ID in SAP Cloud Identity Services
entry.content:
Dear SAP Community,

We are currently building a business application in Entra ID that provisions users into the Identity Directory of the SAP Cloud Identity Services. At this stage, we are not using source or target transformations; instead, we are pushing users and attributes directly from Entra ID into the Identity Directory of our SAP Cloud Identity Services tenant.

In SAP Cloud Identity Services, we have several groups that were created either by SAP Support or by various SAP applications. For example, SAP Joule for Consultants requires a license group called SAP_JOULE_PREMIUM_CONSULTANT, which is created by SAP Support.

Users should be added to these groups automatically based on their group membership in Entra ID. Using the SCIM API, it should be possible to add members to an existing SAP Cloud Identity Services group.

Our target scenario looks like that: A user requests permissions for a specific (SAP-)application via our Entra ID Service Portal. After approval by the user‚Äôs manager, the user is added to an Entra ID group. During the next provisioning cycle, the transformation should work as follows: If the user is a member of Entra ID group ‚ÄúX‚Äù, then they should be added to group ‚ÄúY‚Äù in SAP Cloud Identity Services. If they are no longer part of this group, they should be removed from it again.

Has anyone successfully implemented a similar setup and can share how they approached it?

entry.title: Key Updates from TechEd 2025 That You Will Want to Know as a Data Engineer
entry.content:
A data engineer‚Äôs responsibilities include creating dependable pipelines, reproducible transformations, clear lineage, low-cost operations, and the ability to deliver data products that downstream teams can trust and reuse. With SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC), data engineers can make significant impact using tools built for reliability, scalability, and innovation. At SAP TechEd 2025, SAP unveiled new innovations in SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) and SAP HANA Cloud, that provide data engineers with practical capabilities to deliver on those goals. The two major updates include the release of SAP Snowflake and Data Product Studio in SAP BDC. 

Starting with Data Product Studio, this new BDC capability is a metadata-driven workspace in SAP Business Data Cloud. It allows data engineers to create, model, and manage reusable data products using both visual tools and SQL-based transformations from a single workspace. Users can define schema, lineage, and logic to blend SAP and non-SAP data into governed assets with full version control and lifecycle management. This provides a simpler way to cross-pollinate data products across lines of business and ensure a consistent definition of data across your business data fabric. 

In short, it makes datasets behave like software as it‚Äôs testable, versioned, and promotable, so you stop rebuilding the same pipelines and start shipping dependable, governable data products. This is especially beneficial for you as a data engineer as it frees them from repetitive operational work so they can spend more time on architecture, performance, and delivering reliable data across the enterprise. 
 
Secondly, SAP announced SAP Snowflake, a partnership with Snowflake that brings the full data and AI capabilities of Snowflake as a solution extension to SAP Business Data Cloud. With zero‚Äëcopy access, engineers can query SAP‚Äëmanaged data products in Snowflake without ETL/replication, replication monitoring, or egress troubleshooting, giving immediate access to context rich SAP datasets as if they lived in Snowflake ‚Äì and vice versa. Because SAP preserves semantics and lineage across the connection, teams avoid reverse‚Äëengineering SAP schema quirks, reduce transformation layers and reconciliation cycles, and can prototype AI/ML workloads faster. The result is cleaner, faster pipelines and true hybrid workflows. You can run heavy analytics and ML in Snowflake, then return results to SAP applications without building new ingestion jobs, and keep governance, cataloging, and auditability centralized in BDC. 

Ultimately, the Data Product Studio and the SAP Snowflake launch are key highlights from TechEd 2025 that data engineers should be excited about. These updates mean fewer ad‚Äëhoc rebuilds, faster and safer schema evolution, and the ability to integrate data artifacts into CI/CD pipelines for predictable, auditable releases.  

Rewatch these TechEd sessions to learn more about the Data Product Studio and SAP Snowflake:

  • SAP Business Data Cloud solution road map (DA806v). This session is great for understanding where the Data Product Studio sits in the BDC roadmap, GA timing, and planned integrations with the catalog and governance features. 
  • SAP Business Data Cloud: Strategy, architecture, and vision (ST107v). This session is a great architecture view (how Studio, catalog, lineage, and runtime fit together) and shows operational implications for platform teams. 
  • Transforming how people work with Joule technology (ST123v). This session is helpful if you want to see how data products surface into analytics and how conversational/AI assistants tie into consumption workflows. 

Click on these links to learn more about the BDC features: 

  • Explore the SAP Snowflake Page on SAP.com 
  • Watch a demo video of Data Product Studio 
  • Visit SAP Business Data Cloud on sap.com 
  • View the H2 2025 SAP Innovation Guide

entry.title: SAP API Delta Load not creating delta token
entry.content:
Hi,

We have a requirement to retrieve delta changes from a change log. For this purpose, we created a CDS view with the following delta-related annotations:

@analytics: { dataCategory: #FACT, dataExtraction: { enabled: true, delta: { byElement: { name: 'LastChangeDate', maxDelayInSeconds: 1800 } } } }

We then exposed the CDS view as an OData service using both OData Publish and RAP service binding.
However, when we call the API, the response does not contain any delta link (delta URL).

Could you please advise on how we should proceed?

entry.title: Focused Build's Solution Readiness Dashboard with SAC External Integration
entry.content:
Introduction 

In newest release of Focused Build SP16, the solution readiness dashboard has been enhanced to incorporate external tool integration-related fields within the requirements, work packages, and work items details pages. This integration helps users to track and report on the entities that were initially created or derived from external tools such as JIRA and then transferred to Focused Build. 

Background 

Previously, customers had no way to view or report on external tool integration (Mapping field -external Id) within any Focused Build reporting feature. This limitation resulted in an inability to report on all requirements, work packages, or work items that originated in an external tool and were subsequently transferred to Focused Build. 

Integration Enhancements 

To address these limitations, the field External Id has been made available for reporting in the following areas: 

Requirements 

  • Requirements Details  

External Tool fields in Requirement Details Page

 

 

Work Packages 

  • Work Packages Details  
  • Work Packages KPI Details  
  • Work Packages Distribution  

External Tool fields in Work package Details Page

 

 

Work Items 

  • Work Items Details  
  • Work Items KPI Details  
  • Work Items Distribution  

External Tool fields in Work Item Details Page

 

 Technical details for fetching and displaying the external fields 

Specifics for Requirements: 

For requirements, the reporting includes the combination of the following fields: 

  • CRM_ORDERADM_H-/SALM/EXT_ID: The external tool ID. 
  • System GUID (/SALM/C_EXI_MAPP-GUID_EXT): The globally unique identifier for the external system. 

These fields are necessary to correctly map the external system and the corresponding ID. 

Specifics for Work Packages and Work Items: 

For work packages (WPs) and work items (WIs), the reporting requirements are more specific: 

  • The combination of‚ÄØCRM_ORDERADM_H-/SALM/EXT_ID‚ÄØand‚ÄØExternal System Profile (/SALM/C_EXI_PRJ-EXI_PROFILE)‚ÄØmust be included for reporting. 
  • This is only applicable‚ÄØwhen CRM_ORDERADM_H-/SALM/EXI_ACTIVE = 'X'‚Äîindicating that integration with the external tool is active. 

Benefits 

With these enhancements, customers now have the ability to: 

  • Track and report on the entities derived/created in external tools. 
  • Enhance reporting and visibility, ensuring that external tool integrations are accurately tracked and managed. 
  • Also, it is possible to extract the external tool related fields to an excel from respective detailed pages of solution readiness dashboard. 

Important Links and Resources: 

Focused Build for Solution Manager 
 
Agile Project Delivery with Focused Build for SAP Solution Manager 

ALM Community page

entry.title: SAP Fiori Innovation Day in Walldorf featured two hands-on sessions plus AI everywhere
entry.content:
SAP Fiori Innovation Day in Walldorf continued the momentum of the UX Foundation team showing the latest embedded AI features in My Home and the SAP Fiori elements framework. At our event on December 9, 2025, customers spent a day learning, developing, and networking with each other, SAP experts, and the sponsors.

Hands-on sessions showed how AI speeds application development

New for this iteration of SAP Fiori Innovation Day, we added an additional hands-on session beyond our usual one where people develop an SAP Fiori elements app using building blocks. The new one allowed people to try agentic app development with common AI clients and SAP‚Äôs MCP servers. This is a great way to save time creating SAP Fiori apps and an approach we are starting to use at SAP.

We also discussed the quality of AI-created code. Even if AI generates something faster than you could on your own, it is mandatory for you to understand the code so you can check it in with confidence and explain (or defend) anything during a code review. One of our architects explained that ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know; the AI wrote this part‚Äù is not an acceptable answer. His main message was: ‚Äúas a developer, you own the code.‚Äù

Graphic of the schedule for SAP Fiori Innovation Day in Walldorf

SAP Fiori continues to evolve to make SAP Cloud ERP easier to use

The day started with an overview of SAP Fiori and what this looks like in SAP S/4HANA Cloud. It included a discussion of the SAP Design System and how that includes common themes for UX consistency and enterprise product standards such as accessibility to help both designers and developers create applications that end users love.

Graphic showing overall strategy for SAP‚Äôs products

Demos illustrated and reinforced the points made in the slides. Similar to how you would begin your day with SAP Cloud ERP, we started with My Home and all the different ways you have to launch apps and make the page your own. The intro session also covered adjacent UX topics such as SAP Build Work Zone, SAP Start, and SAP‚Äôs mobile apps as well as a discussion of Joule and how it adds value across SAP‚Äôs portfolio.

Graphic showing Joule interaction patterns.

SAP Fiori includes more AI capabilities for business users

The afternoon demos were split into generally available and beta functionality in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. The released functionality included:

My Home

  • Card creation in My Home‚Äì creates cards that display essential business data that you can add to My Home
  • Joule-assisted insight card creation in My Home‚Äì ask Joule for the information you need and create a card that you can add to My Home
  • Recap ‚Äì shows changes to tasks, cards, and app since you last accessed the system, making it easy to see what you missed when you were away

The recap feature in My Home shows you what changed in the system since your last access.

SAP Fiori elements apps

  • Easy filter ‚Äì natural language searching in SAP Fiori elements list reports
  • Smart summarization ‚Äì AI-created summary of SAP Fiori elements object pages
  • Error explanation ‚Äì AI-assisted content that explains the meaning of error and provides suggestions on how to clear the error condition

Later in our ‚Äúthe future (one more thing)‚Äù session, we shared with some previews of planned AI functionality that will first be released into SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Editon.

  • Easy Fill ‚Äì copies text from an email or other source into the relevant fields on an object page
  • AI-assisted task automation (development code name ‚ÄúSmart Helpers‚Äù) ‚Äì allows business users to automate steps in one or more SAP Fiori apps to streamline a complex process

Easy fill is currently in beta testing with selected public cloud customers. AI-assisted task automation is still in development.

The partners shared different ways to build the future you want in your SAP environment

The gold sponsors for SAP Fiori Innovation Day, eXXcellent solutions, cbs, and sovanta,  presented on topics that engaged the audience as each focused on solving a specific problem common to SAP ERP customers.

  • eXXcellent talked about how to add AI capabilities to your SAP system, even if you are running SAP S/4HANA on-prem.
  • cbs covered how to decrypt SAP error messages with AI, BTP, and a little magic from a tool they have created called ADAM.
  • sovanta discussed how to prioritize what apps to develop, since the cost of building apps is dropping significantly due to AI.

Thanks to everyone who made SAP Fiori Innovation Day a success

  • SAP Presenters (in order of appearance): Thomas Reiss, Katrin Polloczek, Ioannis Grammatikakis, Yeganeh Hajimiri, Katya Bondarenko, Marcel Kassner, Christoph Gollmick.
  • Gold sponsors eXXcellent solutions, cbs, and sovanta
  • Silver sponsors: Uniorg and STELACON
  • Behind the scenes team: all the developers, architects, product managers and other colleagues who built the features we showed, tested the systems, wrote the documentation, packaged the demos, and created the hands-on exercises.
  • Our executive sponsors: Alex Lingg, Ioannis Grammatikakis, Sebastian Steinhauer, Katja Zoch
  • Special thanks to Sebastian Werner and Conny Kinateder for all the logistics work that made everything run smoothly for the customers and partners.

Thanks to all the participants for their enthusiasm and great, probing questions throughout the event. Your feedback on what we showed helps us prioritize our development going forward. The conversations in the hallway, at the coffee machine, and during meals give us a deeper sense of where you are in your SAP Fiori adoption and how we can best serve your interests.

Next steps

  • Register for the monthly SAP Fiori development roundtable call to meet other developers and architects who build SAP Fiori apps.
  • Subscribe to the SAP Fiori development newsletter, in which we share updates on SAP Fiori elements, SAP Fiori tools, SAPUI5, and SAP Build Code every other month.  
  • Join us at an SAP Fiori Development Innovation Day in 2026 ‚Äì we are looking at locations, dates, and some new event formats.

On behalf of the SAP UX Foundation Team, Peter Spielvogel.

Context

  • Our requirement is very limited and specific:
    We mainly need WM for organizational structure purposes, i.e. to create WM warehouses (warehouse numbers) ‚Äì not for complex warehouse processes or decentralized EWM.

Specific questions

  1. Which exact scope item in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition represents this ‚Äúsmall WM‚Äù?

  2. Is this scope always included in the standard Public Cloud license, or is it separately licensable?

entry.title: Re: Service Contract Item List - custom fields
entry.content:
Hi @Sorosch_Sakhiza,

thanks for raising the question. 

According to SAP's current design, custom fields cannot be directly added as columns to the item overview table in the "Manage Service Contracts" app. The "Service Contract Item List" is not included in the personalization options for custom fields in the current application design.

To have custom fields available in the personalization options of the item overview table, you should Submit a feature request through the Customer Influence Portal.

Best regards,
Julius - SAP Cloud ERP Consulting

entry.title: Re: Analytical reporting on fiscal year using a single ba...
entry.content:
Hello @mariana_prusorova 

Thank you for your question.

Yes, one G/L account per category plus rich dimensions is the best practice in public cloud; as long as you model your required analytics as characteristics. Let me explain:

Based on your description, the best practice is to minimise the number of balance sheet G/L accounts and use either the standard or custom universal journal dimension to get the analytical views you need. Instead of keeping many historic accounts for investments, provisions or retained earnings, you should keep one account per category and analyse by fiscal year, business partner or customer using the universal journal and additional characteristics. This Blog provides some insight details: Why YCOA? The value of the standard Chart of Accounts in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.

Should you have missing characteristics, create custom fields on the journal entry for example ProvisionCategory or InvestmentCategory in the Custom Fields app. Make sure you enable them for posting and reporting. Use Manage Substitution app to fill them. These fields become part of ACDOCA and you can use them in Custom Analytical Queries to produce views such as retained earning by year, provisions by business partner and investments by customer without multiplying your G/L accounts.

Here are some helpful references:

Chart of Accounts: Different Types (Two-System Landscape)

Custom Fields for Journal Entries Used in G/L Accounting

How to Upload Extension Fields?

 

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Specification Management in SAP Integrated Product Development ‚Äì What‚Äôs AI got to do with it?
entry.content:
In today‚Äôs blog, I would like to let you know how SAP IPD is leveraging AI and seamless integration to transform the way organizations manage product specifications, collaborate with suppliers, and drive sustainability.

Furthermore, at the end of this blog, I am including the link to our latest Expert Talk, featuring SAP Product Expert Felix Reichle who talked about the latest insights from customers who are already using the latest advancements of SAP IPD in their daily operations.

So let‚Äôs get started!

The Power of Integration: SAP IPD Meets SAP Cloud ERP Private  

One of SAP‚Äôs core goals is to strengthen the integration across business processes, connecting ERP with both upstream and downstream applications. The integration of SAP IPD with SAP Cloud ERP delivers significant value for specification management:

  • Streamlined Collaboration: Internal product developers and external suppliers collaborate efficiently in dedicated spaces, accelerating both product development and procurement.
  • Advanced Collaboration Tools: Features like task assignment, notifications, and historical tracking keep all stakeholders aligned and operations transparent.
  • Enhanced Authorization & Control: Robust authorization and workflow management ensure sensitive data is secure and supplier engagement is auditable.
  • Specification Comparison & Decision Support: Users can easily compare specifications‚Äîeven across multiple suppliers‚Äîsupporting informed, up-to-date decisions.
  • Efficient Document & Workflow Management: Automated notifications and document summarization reduce manual effort and speed up approvals.
  • Supplier Management Integration & Traceability: The integration with supplier management in SAP Cloud ERP Private enables efficient, traceable exchanges and supports collaboration with multiple suppliers at once.

So What‚Äôs New in Specification Management?

SAP IPD‚Äôs enhanced specification management centralizes all product data, creating a true single source of truth. Our latest key innovations include

  • Dynamic Property Tree Visualization: Organize properties visually, assign them to specification types, and support multilingual definitions and inheritance templates for efficient data management.
  • AI-Enabled Search & Comparison: Prompt-based AI search and advanced comparison tools (including composition comparison) make finding and analyzing specifications faster and more intuitive.
  • Integrated Status Management: Define and manage lifecycle statuses for each specification type, with clear actions and descriptions.
  • Sustainability & Compliance: All relevant parameters are stored alongside product data, simplifying reporting and downstream processes.
  • Multiple Validity Dimensions: Manage different versions and regional variations of specifications seamlessly.
  • Workflow Integration: Trigger predefined or automatic processes, such as approval workflows, based on status changes.

And why do our Customers Choose SAP IPD for Collaboration?

Customers are turning to SAP IPD to streamline specification sharing and control access, accelerate compliance, enable OEMs to share critical data with suppliers in a controlled, auditable way, and to allow suppliers to easily access, respond to, and trace specifications, supporting rapid and accurate product development.

Driving Sustainability Goals

Sustainability is a top priority for many organizations. SAP IPD Specification Management helps customers achieve their goals by requiring suppliers to provide compliance certificates, ensuring products meet regulatory and company standards. The system analyzes sustainability data‚Äîlike carbon footprint‚Äîduring specification comparisons, enabling informed, environmentally conscious decisions. Detailed property trees and compositional tables help maintain quality and transparency throughout the supply chain. By embedding sustainability checks and data analysis into supplier collaboration, the solution promotes responsible sourcing and continuous improvement toward sustainability goals.

The Role of Artificial Intelligence

AI is transforming product development by streamlining ideation, documentation, and navigation. In SAP IPD, AI simplifies product specification search makes it easier for users‚Äîespecially in industries impacted by complex regulations like tariffs‚Äîto find relevant information. Instead of navigating complicated field names and parameters, users can search using natural language, allowing the system to quickly filter and present the needed specifications. This intuitive approach improves accuracy, reduces the need for deep technical knowledge, and enhances the experience for both new and occasional users. Additionally, SAP‚Äôs AI assistant Joule further streamlines data discovery and boosts creativity within Specification Management.

So What‚Äôs Coming up on the Roadmap?

Looking ahead to 2026, I would like to point out two items on our roadmap : The integration with SAP Cloud ERP Private EHS Specifications for hybrid scenarios:

  • Use expanded AI capabilities like natural language document search, advanced document summaries, and collaboration search.

  • A deeper integration with the SAP Cloud ERP Private Change Management process

 

So as you can see, SAP IPD‚Äôs Specification Management is optimizing supply chains with enhanced collaboration and AI-powered features. With a strong roadmap and a commitment to sustainability, we want you to succeed in today‚Äôs rapidly changing markets.

Want to learn more?

Tune into our recent Expert Talk with SAP Product Expert Felix Reichle who talked about the latest news in Specification Management and gave an outlook on what‚Äôs coming next: Specification Management in SAP Integrated Product Development.

Don‚Äôt hesitate to leave a comment and check out our community page to ask your questions and engage with the experts. Follow the PSCC_Enablement tag to stay up to date with our latest blog posts. 

Follow me on LinkedIn and stay up-to-date with our latest enablement assets: linkedin.com/in/annette-garcia-lorenzo

entry.title: Integrating SAP Signavio with SAP Solution Manager Focused Build: A Practical Approach
entry.content:
1. Introduction

Large-scale SAP S/4HANA transformation projects includes not only the introduction of new systems and processes but often also the extension or modernization of the existing toolchains. In complex project environments, the seamless integration of process modeling and Application Lifecycle Management (ALM) tools is increasingly critical. Since SAP Cloud ALM could not yet provide all required functionalities for complex transformation projects at the project's start, the customer preferred their existing SAP Solution Manager Focused Build environment. Rather than using the well integrated "out-of-the-box" workflow, an enhanced and customer-optimized toolchain was implemented, as previously discussed in the blog post " The Toolchain of a SAP S/4HANA Transformation‚Äù.

The existing Solution Manager landscape served multiple purposes, company-wide operations support and other ongoing  projects. This context also influenced our integration strategy.

This article describes a practical integration approach for SAP Signavio with SAP Solution Manager Focused Build using the new Business Process Model Connector for SAP Signavio Solutions. The objective is to examine a simple practical integration and collaboration of both tools in a transformation project, providing insights into the implementation procedure, specific configurations, challenges, and the added value of their combined use.

 

2. Project Setup and Toolchain

For this project, the existing Solution Manager Focused Build toolchain was enhanced with additional tools to meet evolving customer requirements. The core objective was to integrate new tools in a manner that supports existing processes and governance regulations while optimally fitting into the customer's Requirement-to-Deploy (R2D) process. The following tools comprise the integrated toolchain:

  • Existing SAP Solution Manager 7.2 with Focused Build: Fully integrated management of software changes, including transport control to connected systems, test management, and go-live and operation and optimization functionalities. Automatic synchronization of development and test management tasks from Jira. Used to create and manage transports across the system landscape and Test and Defect Management.
  • new SAP Signavio: Functions as the leading tool for process modeling and governance. Technical documentation of business processes using BPMN 2.0 models. Provides a scope framework for requirements and discussions about the target state.
  • New SAP Signavio Business Process Model Connector: Transfers BPMN-based process models from Signavio to the Solution Manager Business Process Hierarchy (BPH). The latest connector version operates as a standalone cloud application on SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP). Technical implementation details are outside the scope of this article.
  • Existing Jira: Project management platform for structuring tasks, deadlines, and workflows. Single source of truth for all pending tasks and topics in the program, Documentation, assignment, and collaboration for task completion. Jira supports requirements management, release and project planning. 
  • Existing Confluence: Central and transparent repository/information source for everything. The place to prepare and store results documents, specifications, technical designs, etc. (not the primary focus of this article).
  • LeanIX: Supports architecture management. Modeling and recording of the target architecture and the roadmap
    (not the primary focus of this article).

 

3.   Practical Approach in the Project

3. 1 Procedure and Methods

The customer's Solution Manager had been in use for many years, with an existing solution and branch concept shared across multiple projects. Over time, the Solution Documentation (SolDoc) had become extensive and somewhat unwieldy. To simplify the project setup, a new, separate, empty solution was created specifically for this project, with no dependencies on other projects. Users requiring access to processes or documents from the legacy solution could do so by switching solutions.

Only the new solution is linked to SAP Signavio via the Business Process Model Connector for SAP Signavio Solutions. This approach enables independent operation and clear separation from other ongoing company projects. Any content available within the company or provided by SAP - such as Model Company or Best Practice content - is imported and used exclusively within Signavio.

Process modeling is performed exclusively in Signavio, which serves as the "Single Source of Truth," while Solution Manager functions solely as a repository of processes and process steps for implementation, testing, and deployment. Technical documentation is maintained exclusively in Confluence and linked to processes in Jira. For testing purposes, processes and process steps are used to store and assign test cases, with Signavio serving as the source for creating test cases and variants.

Within the organization, processes are modeled using a value chain approach, with a distinction between as-is and to-be processes. Following modeling and technical/functional release of the to-be processes, they are synchronized with Solution Manager via the Business Process Model Connector for SAP Signavio Solutions at the start of the realization phase, created in the design branch, and made available for further processing in the standard R2D process.

SAP SolDoc (Solution Documentation) and SAP Signavio use hierarchical structures to map processes, with Signavio providing the modeling environment where SAP's standard process levels (like Areas, Groups, Scenarios, Processes, Steps).  Building a 4-tier structure was also not a problem in either world. Other functions in SolDoc, such as executable files/transactions visualized in BPMN, linking business processes with technical details, etc., are handled in Signavio and do not require synchronization with SolDoc.When processes change during the project (e.g., due to new or modified requirements), a new process version (copy) is created in Signavio. Each released process version required for implementing a requirement is then manually synchronized and created in Solution Manager as a separate new version with all process steps. Process steps are created as originals. Visual diagrams are not transferred, and subprocesses are transferred as links but not actively used. Further Attributes from Signavio are currently not transferred. Since executables are not required for the R2D process and testing, this is omitted, eliminating manual post-implementation steps.

A Signavio process version is therefore stored as a version in the Solution Manager SolDoc and utilized in sprints, waves, and releases during requirements implementation. Process steps are not numbered, as this is unnecessary in Signavio and provides no added value in Solution Manager. Given the complexity and nesting of some processes, numbering Signavio activities would be impractical.

Business process modeling and changes occur exclusively in Signavio; no modifications to Signavio content are made within Solution Manager. Only the to-be processes to be implemented for specific requirements, work packages, and work items are synchronized into the design branch of Solution Manager at the start of a Realize phase, then implemented using the standard Focused Build workflow. In Signavio, processes are locked after synchronization and set to final after realization. Further changes are always implemented through new versions

3.2 Governance 

Clear organizational and technical separation of maintenance responsibilities minimizes additional effort and potential errors during tool comparison. Process changes or deletions are performed exclusively in Signavio via versioning. Direct deletion or modification options within the solution documentation are prevented.

Since this procedure was not fully established at the project's start, a deletion flag was created as a custom attribute per the connector documentation. It is used to flag deletions in Signavio within the solution documentation, enabling individual decisions about whether and how deletions can occur in the "SAP world."

Custom Field: Deletion Flag

The search model regeneration in every system is critical here. Since no changes or deletions are currently made to accepted processes, this function has not yet been used.

Role Concept and Authorizations

To prevent manual changes to Signavio processes and process steps in SolDoc, an authorization check was implemented. Changes to Signavio processes or process steps are prevented, while creation or assignment of test cases remains possible.

Only certain roles, such as Test Manager, retain the ability to create and modify manual folders and processes to establish structures outside Signavio processes.

The authorization object for Solution Documentation is SM_SDOC, which controls process documentation maintenance. Beyond the SLAN field (which restricts by solution), other fields enable further restrictions. For this project's purposes, defining the SMUDAUTHGR field was sufficient. This field enables defined authorization groups for grouping objects and attributes. Specific authorization groups can be maintained in view cluster SMUD_AUTHG using transaction SM34.

Additionally, individual solution areas can be restricted using the SBRA field, which was not currently implemented.

The SM_SDOC object is found in SAP_SM_SL_* roles and some role-specific single roles such as SAP_OST_FB_ARCHITECT, SAP_OST_FB_PROJ_M, and SAP_OST_FB_CHANGE_M.

A dedicated authorization group was created for the solution, with only test step-relevant attributes and objects added. Additional documents in SolDoc would require corresponding additions. This configuration is currently sufficient, as all process documentation is stored in Jira & Confluence.

The new authorization group is implemented in the SM_SDOC object in the SMUDAUTHGR field within a customer-specific SAP_SM_SL_* role for developers and business analysts. The solution is also entered in the SLAN field.

In addition to the solution, all relevant change control landscapes should be entered for SLAN. Consistent naming across a Solman landscape with multiple Solution Managers is recommended. The ACTV field can then control permitted activities.

Built into an SAP_SM_SL_* role for developers and business architects, users can view SolDoc structures in their solution, cannot make changes, but can create or assign test cases (and versions).

For architects and stream leads, this would require enhancement in a standard Focused Build workflow, as they also add requirements, work packages, and work items to processes. However, in this project, this was implemented via a Jira interface and could be managed using a technical interface user with required authorizations.

The straightforward authorization check for the relevant solution with described restrictions functions effectively. Unfortunately, Focused Build offers no option to restrict to FOBU projects generally. However, the SLAN object can restrict to solution and change control landscapes across many areas, which is valuable for parallel projects.

 

4. Advantages and Disadvantages of the Chosen Approach

Advantages

  • Modern modeling environment: SAP Signavio provides a significantly more modern and professional modeling environment than solution documentation. 
  • Structuring:  The SAP SolDoc structure uses a hierarchical tree that can also be structured in Signavio. (e.g 4 level for Business Area, Scenarios, Processes, and finally granular Process Steps,
  • Clear ownership: Signavio leads for processes, eliminating double maintenance.
  • Selective transfer: Only processes defined and completed within the scope of a realization phase are transferred to Solution Manager.
  • Improved transparency: Simple version management enhances transparency and traceability of changes.
  • Reduced complexity: Synchronizing process data is streamlined.
  • Role separation: Signavio process consultants do not require Solution Manager access.

Disadvantages & Restrictions

  • Integration effort: Initial setup and operation requires generally integration effort.
  • Limited data depth: Integration depth for additional Signavio data (e.g., executables, subprocesses) is limited.
  • Subprocess limitations: Subprocesses and end-to-end scenarios defined in Signavio can only be synchronized to a limited extent in solution documentation, though this is not necessary.
  • Sequencing issues: Process steps in Solution Manager are not created in the correct sequence; test cases should always be created based on Signavio diagrams.
  • Versioning: Growing numbers of process versions with original process steps can reduce clarity in Solution Manager and libraries.
  • Manual adjustments required: Some manual adjustments in solution documentation are necessary (e.g., creating additional folders and structures for testing or storage of process-independent test cases, folder structure, authorization assignment).
  • No automatic sync from the Solution Manager to Signavio once a process has been implemented.

 

5. Challenges and Lessons Learned

Launching the "new tool" SAP Signavio and achieving simple, meaningful integration with the "legacy"  SAP Solution Manager Focused Build via the Business Process Model Connector for SAP Signavio Solutions required substantial preparation and coordination across project teams.

The primary challenge involved merging and delineating the two tool environments. The "Single Source of Truth" principle for process modeling (Signavio) while avoiding redundant maintenance in Solution Manager proved highly effective. The consistent procedure of handling each process version independently and systematically preventing changes in Solution Manager was particularly valuable.

As in all projects, collaboration and coordination among project members is important. To-be processes modeled in Signavio during the Explore phase must be available in the relevant version in Solution Manager at the latest by the start of the Realize phase.

Limitations were evident in the Focused Build authorization model, which does not enable true project-specific separation. However, workarounds using dedicated solutions, selective roles, specific system authorizations, and systematic assignment of rights to solutions ensure necessary security and controllability.

 

6. Conclusion

The integration of SAP Signavio with SAP Solution Manager Focused Build via the SAP Business Process Model Connector for Signavio demonstrates a pragmatic approach to bridging modern process modeling capabilities with established ALM tooling. While the integration requires careful planning, clear governance, and specific authorization configurations, the benefits of establishing Signavio as the Single Source of Truth for process modeling while leveraging Solution Manager's mature R2D capabilities provide significant value in complex S/4HANA transformation projects.

entry.title: SAP Datasphere News in November
entry.content:
SAP Datasphere News in November

Another month with two great new releases ‚ú®

Learn more in my short top features video in November2025 on YouTube üì∫ and a recap from SAP TechEd this year in the blog üìù below, where you also find more details about the foundational learning journey ‚Äì Becoming an SAP Data Architect.

In addition, explore the latest updates in our community news blogs and more.

 

 

My top features in November

 

Define Row-Level Authorizations Based on IdP User Attributes

This small enhancement is very powerful and my favorite feature of November. You can now use values in custom attributes provided by your identity provider as identifiers in your data access controls and define conditions that apply to users with these values. Why is that powerful? Because using these attributes allows you to apply a single condition to all users whose accounts contain the specified attribute value. In other words, you can group users with attributes to assign permissions to a group instead of individual users.

‚û°Ô∏è  More information.

 

Cancel the Start or Stop Process of an Elastic Compute Node

When an elastic compute node is starting or stopping, you can now cancel the process. The data is rolled back and restored to the state that existed before the start or stop process was initially triggered.

‚û°Ô∏è  More information.

 

Replication Flows: Increase Maximum Parallel Job

You can increase the maximum number of parallel jobs up to 16 to run replication flows. Before, that maximum was 10, so this increase is helpful when you need more parallelization for certain flows.

More information:
‚û°Ô∏è  Configure the Size of Your SAP Datasphere Tenant and
‚û°Ô∏è  Sizing, Capacity Planning, and Load Balancing for Replication Flows

 

New Incremental Aggregation Types for Transformation Flows in a File Space

The aggregation types MIN, MAX, COUNT*, and AVG have been added to the already existing types LAST, SUM, and COUNT. 

‚û°Ô∏è  More information.

 

Transformation Flows: Cancel a Running Merge Task

From the Local Tables (File) monitor, you can now cancel a merge task that is running with a new Cancel button.

‚û°Ô∏è  More information.

 

Disable Delta Capture for Local Tables (File)

When creating a local table (file) from the table editor or as a target of your transformation flow, you can disable the delta capture settings.

More information:
‚û°Ô∏è  Creating a Local Table (File) and
‚û°Ô∏è  Creating a Transformation Flow in a File Space.

 

 

SAP TechEd 2025

I had the opportunity to be onsite in Berlin at SAP TechEd 2025 as well as in Sydney for SAP TechEd on tour. It was great to see so many people in person at both events. After many years of virtual TechEd‚Äôs this was excellent. Not only meeting many friends but also having those inspiring discussions with new people from various customers, partners, and also colleagues from SAP.

Session DA203 together with Dominik Kurz was recorded as part of the virtual SAP TechEd and can be watched here: 
üîó  https://www.sap.com/events/teched/virtual/flow/sap/tev25/catalog-virtual/page/catalog/session/1754495722564001nPF0

 

Happy to share that my deep dive session ‚ÄúThe impact of SAP Business Data Cloud on SAP Datasphere users‚Äù made it to the top 5 most attended sessions overall in Berlin. In general, all sessions around SAP Business Data Cloud drew high participation and our colleagues at the SAP BDC booth were also busy until the last minute on Thursday afternoon.

A highlight was certainly the partnership announcement with Snowflake. The announcement covers two flavors brownfield and greenfield scenarios.
(1) Brownfield: enabling Snowflake systems to be connected via BDC connect, targeted for GA in H1 2026
(2) Greenfield: offering SAP Snowflake on the SAP pricelist as a solution extension, targeted for Q1 2026

A week after TechEd we also announced a partnership with Microsoft at Microsoft Ignite, enabling Microsoft Fabric to be connected via BDC connect, targeted for GA in H3 2026.

That covers now Databricks, Snowflake, Google and Microsoft as technology partners for SAP Business Data Cloud Connect. Not much missing here from my point of view.

 

Becoming an SAP Data Architect - Foundational Learning Journey

 

This is a great learning opportunity for all you data architects out there‚ÄºÔ∏è
Kudos to the learning team together with our architectural experts!

The foundational Learning Journey of becoming an SAP Data Architect is the first step in a comprehensive program designed to empower data professionals and architects of the future. This new learning journey provides a structured path to develop the knowledge, frameworks, and strategic mindset needed to design, govern, and communicate enterprise-scale data architectures.

üß≠  What Is the Data Architecture Learning Journey?

The learning journey is built to create strong Data Architecture foundations moving from foundational principles to strategic business impact. Learners will gain both architectural knowledge and understanding that is essential for any modern data architect and covers the following four units:

üîπFoundational Concepts Learn the core principles and frameworks of data architecture from conceptual, logical, and physical data modelling to metadata management and frameworks.

üîπModern Paradigms & Integration Explore today‚Äôs architectural models like Data Mesh, Data Fabric, and Lakehouse and design integration strategies (ETL, ELT, and streaming) for scalable, real-time analytics.

üîπGovernance, Security & Strategic Impact Build governance frameworks, establish data lineage, safeguard privacy, and align data strategy with business objectives for measurable value.

üîπCommunicating Data Value Strengthen communication and storytelling skills to articulate architectural value, design transformation roadmaps, and drive organizational adoption of data-driven change.

‚ùì Why This Matters

In a world where data is at the core of every business decision, the role of the Data Architect has become critical.

This learning journey helps professionals at every level develop the skills, language, and strategic vision to lead in data architecture and governance.

üëâ  By completing this journey, learners will be able understand how to:

entry.title: SAP BTP: Data Fabric
entry.content:
Irrespective of where your source system resides, SAP provides the capabilities to ingest, harmonize and unlock real-time and predictive insights on your target system with confidence. This is supported by resilient, enterprise-grade frameworks, tools, and methodologies that safeguard data quality, integrity, and consistency throughout the entire data lifecycle.

 SAP. (2023). Figure:1

Source Systems for Data Provisioning in SAP

URL: https://learning.sap.com/courses/implementing-data-provisioning-in-sap-bw-4hana/identifying-sap-bw-4hana-source-systems-and-their-use-cases

 

The endless possibilities of raw, intrinsic data ingestion from e.g. Enterprise warehouses, data lakes, rational & in-memory databases, SaaS applications even social media into SAP HANA (On-premises and/ or Cloud) opens a world of opportunity for data engineers to acquire rich, accurate, and complete master and transactional data from all possible sources imaginable. Responsibility for managing the data acquisition processes depends on the provisioning type being used. Common approaches include:

Provisioning Type

Data Flow Responsibility

Metadata Management

Typical Use Cases

Application-Controlled

Source application pushes data to target using APIs or connectors.

Managed in application layer (schema, mappings, transformations).

Custom logic, application-driven workflows, SaaS integrations.

Change Data Capture (CDC)

CDC engine streams changes (insert/update/delete) from source to target in near real-time.

Managed by CDC tool (change logs, timestamps, transaction markers).

Real-time replication, incremental updates, event-driven architectures.

Database-Controlled

Target database pulls data from source using adapters or SDI.

Centralized in database layer (schemas, lineage, governance).

Governance-heavy environments, centralized data lakes, enterprise ETL.

Figure:2

Provisioning Types: Data Flow & Metadata Management

 

The utilization of high-performance ETL/ELT tools ensure the consistence, quality and reliability of the data is upheld and thus often used to unify the data to best meet the objectives of the stakeholder‚Äôs request either being executives, decision makers, marketing or product. A well-thought-out data provisioning strategy should always take precedence as this ensure a smooth flowing data process. Depending on the usage of the data, a data engineer may explorer the below different data provisioning approaches:

  • Data federation ‚Äì Data is not loaded nor persisted into the target system (SAP HANA) but rather read directly from the source system only when the data is needed for use.
  • Data replication ‚Äì Data from the source system is loaded, persisted into the target system and kept in sync using various mechanisms
    • Real-time (Synchronous) replication
    • Delta load (asynchronous)replication
  • Data transformation ‚Äì The raw data is enhanced with additional features e.g. calculation columns, renamed fields or new fields derived from other exiting fields

SAP provides but not limited to the below high-performance native data integration technologies:

Tool

Primary Function

Position in Landscape Architecture

SLT (SAP Landscape Transformation Replication)

Real-time replication (CDC)

Integration layer between SAP sources and HANA DB

SDA (Smart Data Access)

Virtual access to remote sources (federation)

Integration layer enabling query pushdown to the HANA DB

SDI (Smart Data Integration)

ETL/ELT pipelines, adapters, dataflows

Integration layer moving and transforming data before loading into the HANA DB

Figure 3:

SAP Native ETL/ELT tools

Furthermore, for Data quality, cleansing and enrichment before persisting into the HANA DB, SAP provides the below:

  • Smart Data quality (SDQ) for SAP HANA on-premises
  • Data Quality Management Microservices (DQMm) as a subscription-based microservice for SAP HANA Cloud

 

SAP Hana provides a variation of consolidated tools both on premise and in the cloud, all providing for various functionality for different use cases such as:

  • Supporting data provisioning  
  • Developing Database artefacts
  • Monitoring the performance of the develop artefacts
  • Monitoring the Database and its system performance
  • Administering and managing the Database

One of the key strengths of the SAP ecosystem is the ability to seamlessly combine cloud functionalities together with on-premises and still import specific/ needed applications as micro services into common IDE‚Äôs such as Microsoft Visual Studio code is commendable because it:

  • Provides business with a comprehensive 360-degree view of
    • Database health overview.
    • Data life cycle from end to end.
    • Application life cycle from end to end.
  • Empowers the end users, data engineers, developers, data scientists, data analyst and support engineers with greater power and flexibility over the data being used.

Below are native tools used by SAP for various purposes:

  • SAP Business Application studio ‚Äì Cloud development tool.
  • Web IDE ‚Äì On-premises development tool
  • SAP Hana cockpit - a web-based tool for monitoring, administering, and managing SAP HANA databases, offering a centralized, browser-accessible interface with tile-based dashboards for performance, resource usage (CPU, memory, disk), alerts, and security. It allows tasks like starting/stopping services, managing users, viewing alerts, analyzing performance, and running SQL queries through its integrated Database Explorer. 

SAP SaaS applications are imported into common IDE, s such as Microsoft Visual Studio code via extensions, libraries etc. for a specific purpose e.g.:

  •  Supportability tools for SAP HANA - For both online and offline performance analysis and troubleshooting. With a focus on the needs of support engineers, the performance analysis tools provide enhanced analysis options for trace files and runtime dump files, as well as allowing in-depth analysis on extensive datasets.
  • The SQL analyzer tool for SAP HANA - A performance analysis tool that helps developers visualize and understand SQL execution plans. Designed for query tuning and optimization, it offers detailed insights into how queries run within the SAP HANA database.
  • SAP HANA Database Explorer - Provides functionality for accessing SAP HANA databases, browsing the database catalog, and executing SQL from a SQL console.

Figure 4:

SAP Development and Administration Tools Overview

 

The consolidated toolset further enhances productivity and convenience for end users, data engineers, developers, data scientists, data analyst and support engineers by enabling them to access all essential capabilities from a single unified platform. The choice and flexibility to work with the desired programming languages ranging from but not limited to: SQL, SQL Script, Python, Node.js, JavaScript and react native etc. Enable a cross-functional team with diverse skill set to collaborate effectively while striving towards the same common goal.

 Figure 5:

Core Programming Languages and Frameworks for SAP HANA Cloud and On-Premises

 

After successfully completing the Explore phase, with a solid fit -to-standard analysis of proposed use cases, Extrinsic data pipelines are then implemented for reliable and consistent data flow. These pipelines support a wide range of business needs such as decision making, go-to-market activities or ML/AI use cases requested by various stakeholders. The process is typically executed and maintained by data engineers, developers, data scientists, data analyst and/or support engineers.

The harmonized data is then governed, analyzed, and visualized through multiple front-end applications. These applications are powered by various integration frameworks e.g. REST APIs, OData v4, JDBC/ODBC, each serving different user needs and functional objectives:

 Figure: 6

SAP-Compatible Applications and Their Integration Frameworks

 

Mutatis mutandis, Data is the inception of all there is, as it has been in the beginning, is now and ever shall be. Thank you all for taking a glimpse into the above Content. Please don‚Äôt for get to like, comment and share.

 

Abbreviations:

API: Application Programming Interface

BTP: Business Technology Platform

CDC: Change Data Capture

DB: Database

DQMm: Data Quality Management Microservices

ELT: Extract, Load, Transform

ETL: Extract, Transform, Load

IDE: Integrated Development Environment

ML/AI: Machine Learning/Artificial Intelligence

ODBC: Open Database Connectivity

OData: Open Data Protocol

REST: Representational State Transfer

SaaS: Software as a Service

SDI: Smart Data Integration

SDA: Smart Data Access

SDQ: Smart Data Quality

SLT: SAP Landscape Transformation Replication

SQL: Structured Query Language

 

Reference:

  1. SAP. (2023). Figure:1 Source Systems for Data Provisioning in SAP, URL: https://learning.sap.com/courses/implementing-data-provisioning-in-sap-bw-4hana/identifying-sap-bw-4hana-source-systems-and-their-use-cases

entry.title: Re: SAP Public Cloud 2508 / Errors during the Mass Creati...
entry.content:
Hello @LukasKuhn 

Thank you for your question.

Yes, and it is a standard behaviour. The simple reason for that error is, the system works in packages and that is set to 100 relationships. Basically, saying you may have ‚Äúexceeded the limit‚Äù.

Let me explain, the error is caused by the MDG mass creation framework locking BP relationships while the technical user SAP _WFRT activates them in the background. This explains why you see about 100 BPs activated, then lock, then another 100 until all 500 are done.

I recommend you activate 500 in the process you are now, click activate just once and let the background job finish. You can monitor through the process log and Application Jobs, rather than re-triggering activation. Also, consider running these jobs when there is less traffic (off-peak hours).

If it is extremely slow, you may consider opening a ticket with SAP to better analyse the performance in your tenant.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Making SAP Business One Web Client accessible externally using nginx as a reverse proxy
entry.content:
Hi,

why does the web client architecture require that also SLD and Authentication Service are published?
Isn'T there a possibility to only expose web client and handle the login via internal connections or over the service layer connection?

Based on our internal security guidelines we have separated web client to a dedicated server.
Intention is to have a different update and restart cycle for this Linux machine. And the idea that web client only knows about the service layer connection and doesn't need more.

For our understanding SLD has always been the heart of a B1 installation which knows all about installed services, databases, users etc.
We published web client via Citrix Netscaler only to realize that we would need additional netscaler addresses for SLD and Authentication service which will lead to additional discussions with our security team and also require maintenance of these adresses for different environments.

Is publishing of SLD really required? Are there plans to change that?
Thanks!

entry.title: SAP Business Cloud Trial Limitation : Why?
entry.content:
Hi SAP Team,

I would like to understand which features are unavailable in the SAP BDC Trial and the reasons behind these limitations. The FAQ only provides a generic statement about ‚Äúrestricted use,‚Äù but there is no clear list of what is or isn‚Äôt supported. Below are some key gaps I‚Äôve noticed:

  • Unable to create a new space (and no custom or standard space using data lake storage is available).

  • Unable to create Data Products with the Foundation option, which means they cannot be shared with Databricks.

  • Unable to install new Intelligent Apps or update existing ones such as the Working Capital app.

  • No dummy BW PCE instance, making it impossible to explore or practice subscription options.

  • No Pay-as-you-go subscription option.

  • The minimum ticket size for a paid subscription is north of $1k, without any purchase parity.

There are several other restrictions, but these are the most significant. Please feel free to add more if I‚Äôve missed any.

My main question is: What is the rationale behind enforcing so many restrictions? Why not provide broader access for developers who want to learn, experiment, and upskill on the latest SAP technologies, especially when their organizations haven‚Äôt adopted BDC and they have no access through work?

Platforms like Snowflake, Databricks, AWS, and GCP etc. offer free tiers with essential services, allow account creation with personal email IDs, provide free credits, and enable continued use at a nominal cost with a credit card. By comparison, the SAP Trial is highly limited and lasts only 30 days.

Could you please clarify the thought process behind this approach?

entry.title: Infrastructure as Code on SAP API Management
entry.content:
We are building an API portal on SAP Integration Suite exposing api's from SAP Commerce Cloud for a large global client.

To do this we need to configure provider, proxies, policies, certificates, endpoints, api products etc. on SAP APIM.

We are using 4 BTP instances/environments for this: CI, Dev, QA and Prod.

Since we don't want to manually set up all these resources on each environment, we are building a custom IaC setup, which can configure all these resources automatically from GitHub actions.

Our IaC setup uses the SDK's provided for BTP and APIM to configures the instances. Not an easy task, since the SDK's are very poorly documented by SAP.

Part of the setup is to have GitHub actions run on pull requests to configure an entire resource setup needed for running automated api tests against the API products defined on APIM.

Is anybody else working on something like this?

Is it correct that no official SAP Terraform provider exists for SAP APIM?

entry.title: Is the above list of RFCs Read only?
entry.content:
Hello Experts,

We are investigating an unexpected update on the SAP internal table TTREELOADS. To isolate the cause, we are analyzing which RFC calls might indirectly trigger this update in the system.
UPDATE TTREELOADS
SET GEN_DATE = ..., GEN_TIME = ..., GEN_FLAG = ...
WHERE TREE_ID = ...

Below is the list of RFCs being used. Our understanding is that all of them should be read-only, but we would like to confirm with the community:
RFCs under review

  • RFC_READ_TABLE

  • RFC_SYSTEM_INFO

  • RFC_CLIENT_INFO

  • SWNC_GET_WORKLOAD_SNAPSHOT

  • TH_USER_LIST

  • TH_WPINFO

  • TH_SERVER_LIST

  • TH_REQUEST_QUEUE

  • SAPTUNE_GET_SUMMARY_STATISTIC

  • STFC_CONNECTION

  • GET_SYSTEM_TIME_REMOTE

  • ENQUEUE_READ

  • ICM_GET_INFO2

  • GWY_READ_CONNECTED_GW

  • SCSI_GET_HARDWARE_INFO

  • GET_FSYS_SINGLE

  • GET_CPU_ALL

  • GET_MEM_ALL

  • GET_DISK_SINGLE

  • GET_LAN_SINGLE

  • GET_TOP_SINGLE

  • /SDF/GET_DUMP_LOG

  • /SDF/GET_SYS_LOG

  • /SDF/GET_GW_STATS

  • /SDF/EWA_GET_ABAP_DUMPS

  • /IWFND/SUTIL_LOG_GET_RESULT

  • /IWBEP/SUTIL_LOG_GET_RESULT

    Has anyone encountered any of these RFCs performing internal housekeeping updates (such as triggering TTREELOADS updates), even if no explicit write operation is visible?
    Any insights, SAP notes, or internal behavior details would be greatly appreciated.

    Thank you!

entry.title: Please vote for Enhancement Request for AI for Comp Insights
entry.content:
Compensation Insights does not use data from the Pay Range object. As a result, any updates to the Pay Range after an employee‚Äôs last pay change will not be reflected in the compensation insights.

Example: An employee‚Äôs pay changes on 10-Jul-2025, resulting in a compa-ratio of 95%. On 01-Oct-2025, the Pay Range object is updated with a new salary range.  This new salary range changes their compa-ratio to 105%. This updated compa-ratio is not reflected when the manager generates Compensation Insights.

Please vote the enhancement request below to resolve this issue:

https://influence.sap.com/sap/ino/#/idea/363380

entry.title: Error importing data

Updating the rule in customizing doesn‚Äôt retroactively change existing or manually created lines ‚Äî it only applies during automated determination.

entry.title: SAP EPPM ‚Äì The Muscles and Brain Behind Modern Project Systems
entry.content:
Introduction: 

In the world of enterprise projects, SAP Project System (PS) has been a reliable workhorse for decades. It manages work breakdown structures, costs, and scheduling  which are the muscles of project execution.

With a grown business complexity. Projects should no longer treated as isolated cost objects, they‚Äôre strategic investments that must be evaluated, prioritized, and adjusted dynamically.

And that‚Äôs exactly where SAP Enterprise Portfolio and Project Management (EPPM) steps in bringing the brain and extra muscles that traditional SAP PS has always needed.

 

Shifting from Project Control to Strategic Orchestration : 

Let‚Äôs be honest , the classic SAP PS has served us remarkably well.
It‚Äôs solid, reliable, and seamlessly integrated into our core business processes.

But here‚Äôs the truth: traditional Project Systems were never designed to determine what actually deserves to become a project.

Where the Gap Exists in Classic Project Systems ?

Whenever a new business demand comes, we face the same familiar question:

  • Should we really treat this request as a Project in the first place, or could it be better managed as an Idea, a Proposal, or even a Sales Order?

Answering those questions requires strategic decision-making.

something beyond project control. It calls for a shift toward strategic orchestration.

SAP PS excels once those decisions are made it‚Äôs great at tracking and managing execution.

Based on the highlighted PS limitations here lies the question  What if the decision-making process itself like 

  • How to Classify the business demand in Portfolio(s) under Project managers responsibilities ?
  • How to prioritize the potential projects in pipeline to proceed with them in further decisions ?
  • How to convert business demand from Initial status ( Idea ) to real status ( R&D project) ?
  • How to Choose which projects to launch ?

 

 

That‚Äôs exactly where the evolution from PS to EPPM comes in.

EPPM introduces a strategic layer above PS, Instead of focusing on individual projects, it enables portfolio-level management to evaluating investments, comparing scenarios, balancing capacity and risk, and aligning execution with corporate strategy.

In short, EPPM doesn‚Äôt just give your project system stronger muscles it gives it a smarter brain.

Is it Just an add - On ?

The SAP EPPM is not just an add-on; it‚Äôs a structured ecosystem designed to bridge the gap between strategic planning and project execution.
At its heart, it connects three main layers: Portfolio & Project Management (PPM) , Project Systems (PS), and Commercial project management (CPM).

1. Project and Portfolio Management ‚Äì The Strategic Layer

This is where ideas are born, classified, evaluated, and prioritized.

  • A portfolio is a structured collection of initiatives, projects, programs, or investments that an organization manages to achieve its strategic objectives.
    • It provides a high-level view of all potential and active investments, allowing decision-makers to prioritize, allocate resources, balance risk, and align activities with corporate strategy.

 

  • Portfolio Buckets define funding boundaries and organizational structures, helping align initiatives with corporate strategy.

  • Portfolio Items represent potential investments or business demands.

  • Decision-makers can assess them using financial KPIs, risk scores, and capacity constraints.

  • This layer helps answer the ‚ÄúWhat , When and why‚Äù  what should we invest in, and why now ?

2. Project Management ‚Äì The Tactical Layer

Once an idea proves its worth, it transitions into a Project.

  • Here, Project Management (via SAP PS or PPM Project Management) takes over for detailed planning  timelines, work breakdown structures (WBS), resources, and costs.

  • Project Templates ensure consistency across business units, while integration with SAP Financials, HR, and Logistics keeps execution tightly aligned with operations.
    This layer answers the ‚Äúhow and clear when‚Äù how will we deliver, and precisely when each step will occur.

 

3. Project Execution ‚Äì The Operational Layer

Finally, execution happens through SAP PS, where budgets are consumed, costs are tracked, and progress is reported.

  • Actual costs flow from finance and controlling.

  • Time confirmations, material usage, and procurement are managed here.
    This is where strategies materialize into measurable outcomes.

This layer shows and record what was accomplished and the cost of achieving it.

 

Now,  Let's turning a business case into action: How SAP EPPM Helps us to Decide Wisely

Imagine one company contact us with a request like, ‚ÄúHey, can you implement SAP S/4HANA for our business?‚Äù

It‚Äôs tempting to jump straight into the project but doing so can lead to wasted resources, missed priorities, or surprises down the road.

So, Let's utilized the above concept in evaluating this request.

Step 1: Capture the Business Idea

  • First things first: get the request into the EPPM system

  • In SAP EPPM, each request becomes a Portfolio Item.

  • Assign it to the right Portfolio and Bucket this helps organize requests by responsibilities, Geographical locations, or project type

 

 

  • The above diagram Show that the business request is assigned under the following classification:

    

Region MENA RegionKnow where initiatives are happening
Business TypeImplementationSee what kind of work it is

* MENA region didn't classify the projects based on Budget like APAC area, However, new bucket level can be created to add more classification if needed.

* Portfolio item which is proposed project only can be assigned at the lowest bucket level

Step 2: Check the Feasibility

Before we dive in, we need to make sure the project is worth it and possible.

To determine if the business request worth it we are using the commercial questionnaire assigned to this business request 

  • Commercial Questionnaire example : 

    • Is Proposal meets our expected ROI ?

    • Is customer budget within the acceptable range ?

    • Will it match our strategic revenu policy ?

  • Technical Questionnaire example:

    • Do we have internal capabilities or Training required ?

    • Does client needs complex integration with existing systems?

    • Are external resources needed?

    • Are there timeline or dependency risks?

This step ensures every idea is looked at through both a business and technical lens‚Äîno surprises later.

 

Step 3: Score and Prioritize

After gathering answers, we can evaluate and Prioritize this business request according to our scoring module and which level it meets our strategy.

 

 

In Next steps we are keeping Projects on : Planning, Execution, Monitoring, Evaluation, and Closure Track: 

Once the proposal get evaluated and approved it then flow to:

  • Tactical Layer: Detailed project planning (timelines, resources, WBS)

  • Operational Layer: Execution tracking (SAP PS or integrated systems monitor costs and progress)

This layered approach keeps things organized, measurable, and controllable.

 

Now, Let's Wrapping Up: Driving Success with SAP EPPM

By understanding the three layers of SAP EPPM Strategic, Tactical, and Operational organizations gain a holistic view of how initiatives move from conception to execution. The Strategic Layer ensures that every idea is evaluated against corporate objectives, prioritized according to its potential impact, and aligned with long-term business goals. The Tactical Layer translates approved initiatives into well-structured projects, defining detailed timelines, resource requirements, and cost estimates to ensure precise planning and coordination. Finally, the Operational Layer tracks actual execution, capturing real-time data on costs, resource utilization, progress, and outcomes, allowing organizations to measure performance against planned objectives.

This structured, end-to-end approach not only transforms ideas into measurable results but also empowers leaders to make informed, data-driven decisions, optimize resource allocation, and minimize risks. By integrating strategy, planning, and execution within a single framework, SAP EPPM enables organizations to achieve operational efficiency, maintain financial control, and deliver tangible business value that drives sustainable growth and competitive advantage across the enterprise.
